tit.e: kemari; a type of football played by courtiers in ancient Japan
kemari; a type of football played by courtiers in ancient Japan
Kemari (a type of football played by courtiers in ancient Japan)
tit.cmt: kを大文字にしました。説明を（）に入れました。

sen.j: 蹴鞠（けまり）とは、平安時代に流行した競技のひとつ。
sen.e: The so-called kemari is one of the athletic sports that became popular at Heian Era.
The so-called kemari is one of the athletic sports that became popular during the Heian Era.
Kemari is one of the athletic sports that became popular during the Heian period.
sen.cmt: The so-called 削除Heian Era→Heian periodに変更しました。

sen.j: 鹿皮製の蹴鞠鞠を一定の高さで蹴り続け、その回数の多寡を競う競技である。
sen.e: It is a game in which players competes for the number of times he/she can kick a kemari shuttlecork made of deer skin to a certain height.
It is a game in which players compete for the number of times he/she can kick a kemari shuttlecock made of deer skin to a certain height.
It is a game in which players compete for the number of times he/she can kick a kemari shuttlecock made of deer skin to a certain height.

sen.j: なお、日本語でサッカーのことを「蹴球（しゅうきゅう）」と呼ぶのは、明治時代にヨーロッパから来た外国人が外国人居留地でその競技に興ずる姿を見て、日本人が「異人さんの蹴鞠」と呼んだことからきているといわれる。
sen.e: Moreover, soccer started to be called "shukyu" in Japanese when foreigners who came from Europe at Meiji Era were seen having fun with the game in a foreigners' residential area. It is said that at that time, Japanese people called it "Foreigner's kemari".

Moreover, soccer started to be called "shukyu" in Japanese when foreigners who came from Europe during the Meiji Era and were seen having fun with the game in a foreigners' residential area. It is said that at that time, Japanese people called it "Foreigner's kemari".

Moreover, soccer started to be called 'shukyu' in Japanese when foreigners who came from Europe during the Meiji period and were seen having fun with the game in a foreigners' residential area, and it is said that at that time, Japanese people called it 'foreigner's kemari.'
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。原文の「」に合わせ"を'にEra→periodに変更しました。

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 中国
sen.e: China
China
China

sen.j: 中国の蹴鞠の歴史は紀元前300年以上前の田斉（戦国時代 (中国)）での軍事訓練にさかのぼる
sen.e: The history of kemari of China can be traced back to the military training by Densei earlier than 300 B.C. (Warring States Period in China). In Han Dynasty, it was established as a competing game in which 2 teams of 12 people were striking for the shuttlecork in order to shoot it into the kyumon (goal). Large-scale games were held in the Court.

The history of kemari of China can be traced back to military training by Densei earlier than 300 B.C. (Warring States Period in China). In Han Dynasty, it was established as a competing game in which 2 teams of 12 people were striking the shuttlecock in order to kick it into the kyumon (goal). Large-scale games were held in the Court.
The history of kemari of China can be traced back to military training by Densei earlier than 300 B.C. (Warring States Period in China).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: とされ、漢代には12人のチームが対抗して鞠を争奪し「球門」に入れた数を競う遊戯として確立し、宮廷内で大規模な競技が行われた。
sen.e: In Han Dynasty, it was established as a competing game in which 2 teams of 12 people were striking the shuttlecock in order to kick it into the 'kyumon (goal),' and large-scale games were held in the Court.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理原文の「」に合わせ'を補足一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: 唐代にはルールは多様化し、球門は両チームの間の網の上に設けられたり競技場の真ん中に一個設けられるなどの形になった。
sen.e: In Tang Dynasty, the rules became comprehensive. The goal was put on a net between both teams, and became a single structure at the center of the playground.
In the Tang Dynasty, the rules became comprehensive. The goal was put on a net between both teams, and became a single structure at the center of the playground.
In the Tang Dynasty, the rules became comprehensive, that the goal was put on a net between both teams, and became a single structure at the center of the playground.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: この時期、鞠は羽根を詰めたものから動物の膀胱に空気を入れたよく弾むものへと変わっている。
sen.e: During this period, the shuttlecork changed from a one attached with feathers to an animal's bladder filled with air so that it bounces well.
During this period, the shuttlecock changed from a one with attached feathers to an animal's bladder filled with air so that it bounced well.
During this period, the shuttlecock changed from a one with attached feathers to an animal's bladder filled with air so that it bounced well.

sen.j: またモンゴル帝国の遠征にともなって東欧や東南アジアにも伝来したと言われている。
sen.e: It is also said to be introduced to Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia with the expedition of the Mongolian Empire.
It is also said to be introduced into Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia with the Mongolian expeditions.
It is also said to be introduced into Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia with the Mongolian expeditions.

sen.j: 東南アジアでは現在でも蹴鞠が起源といわれているセパタクロー（蹴る鞠という意味）が盛んである。
sen.e: In Southeast Asia, SepakTakraw (meaning kicked shuttlecork), which is said to be the origin of kemari, is still popular nowadays.
In Southeast Asia, SepakTakraw (meaning kicked shuttlecock), which is said to be the origin of kemari, is still popular nowadays.
In Southeast Asia, SepakTakraw (meaning kicked shuttlecock), which is said to be the origin of kemari, is still popular nowadays.

sen.j: 蹴鞠競技はその後、中国本土では次第に廃れていき、宋 (王朝)代にはチーム対抗の競技としての側面が薄れて一人または集団で地面に落とさないようにボールを蹴る技を披露する遊びとなった。
sen.e: Subsequently, kemari game in mainland China gradually became fading out. In Song Dynasty, team competitions were few. It became a one-man play or group play in which the ball was kicked such that it did not fall onto the ground.

Subsequently,the kemari game in mainland China gradually becamephased out. In the Song Dynasty, team competitions were few. It became a one-man play or group play in which the ball was kicked to keep the ball from falling to the ground.

Subsequently the kemari game in mainland China gradually became phased out, in the Song Dynasty, team competitions were few, and it became a one-man play or group play in which the ball was kicked to keep the ball from falling to the ground.
sen.cmt: 、削除スペース補足一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: やがて貴族や官僚が蹴鞠に熱中して仕事をおろそかにしたり、娼妓が男たちの好きな蹴鞠をおぼえて客たちを店に誘う口実にしたりすることが目立ったため、明初期には蹴鞠の禁止令が出され、さらに清における禁止令で中国からはほぼ完全に姿を消した。
sen.e: Soon, aristocrats and bureaucrats became so enthusiastic about kemari that duties were neglected. Prostitutes who learnt men's favorite kemari and used this as an excuse to invite customers to their shops became so conspicuous that during the early Ming Dynasty, China government issued a prohibition ordinance against kemari. This prohibition continued into the Qing Dynasty, that kemari almost disappeared completely from China.

Soon, aristocrats and bureaucrats became so enthusiastic about kemari that duties were neglected. Prostitutes who learnt men's favorite kemari and used this as an excuse to invite customers to their shops became so conspicuous that during the early Ming Dynasty, the Chinese government issued a prohibition ordinance against kemari. This prohibition continued into the Qing Dynasty, and kemari almost disappeared completely from China.

Soon, aristocrats and bureaucrats became so enthusiastic about kemari that duties were neglected, and prostitutes who learnt men's favorite kemari and used this as an excuse to invite customers to their shops became so conspicuous that during the early Ming Dynasty, the Chinese government issued a prohibition ordinance against kemari; this prohibition continued into the Qing Dynasty, and kemari almost disappeared completely from China.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: 蹴鞠は600年代、仏教などと共に中国より日本へ渡来した。
sen.e: In about 600, kemari was introduced from China to Japan together with the Buddhism etc.
In about 600, kemari was introduced from China to Japan together with the Buddhism etc.
In about 600, kemari was introduced from China to Japan together with the Buddhism etc.

sen.j: 天智天皇と藤原鎌足が、蹴鞠をきっかけに親しくなり、これがきっかけで645年に大化の改新が興ったことは広く知られている。
sen.e: Emperor Tenji and FUJIWARA no Kamatari became intimate because of kemari. It is widely known that, this brought about the Taika Reform in 645.
Emperor Tenji and FUJIWARA no Kamatari became intimate because of kemari. It is widely known that, this brought about the Taika Reform in 645.
Emperor Tenji and FUJIWARA no Kamatari became intimate because of kemari, and it is widely known that, this brought about the Taika Reform in 645.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: 蹴鞠は日本で独自の発達を遂げ、数多の蹴鞠の達人を輩出した（下記蹴鞠蹴鞠の達人の章にて紹介）。
sen.e: Kemari developed and accomplished itself independently in Japan. A lot of experts of kemari have emerged (The following is an introductory session of the experts of kemari).
Kemari developed independently in Japan. Many experts on kemari have emerged (The following is an introduction to the experts of kemari).
Because kemari developed independently in Japan, many experts on kemari have emerged (The following is an introduction to the experts of kemari).
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: 平安時代には蹴鞠は宮廷競技として貴族の間で広く親しまれるようになり、貴族達は自身の屋敷に鞠場と呼ばれる専用の練習場を設け、日々練習に明け暮れたという。
sen.e: During Heian Era, as an athletic sport at Court, kemari was popular among noblemen. Nobleman built private practice ground called "mari-ba" (ball ground) in their own residences. It is said that they spent the whole day practicing every day.

During Heian Era, as an athletic sport at Court, kemari was popular among noblemen. Nobleman built a private practice ground called "mari-ba" (ball ground) on their own residences. It is said that they spent the whole day practicing, every day.

During Heian period, as an athletic sport at Court, kemari was popular among noblemen, therefore nobleman built a private practice ground called "mari-ba" (ball ground) on their own residences, and they spent the whole day practicing, every day.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。Era→periodに変更しました。

sen.j: 辛口の評論で知られる清少納言でさえ、著書「枕草子」のなかで「蹴鞠は面白い」と謳っているほどであった。
sen.e: Even SEI-shonagon, who was well-known by her harsh criticisms, praised highly in her book "Makura-no-soshi" that "Kemari is interesting".
Even SEI-shonagon, who was well-known for her harsh criticism, praised kemari highly in her book "Makura-no-soshi" saying that "Kemari is interesting."
Even SEI-shonagon, who was well-known for her harsh criticism, praised kemari highly in her book '"Makura-no-soshi' saying that 'Kemari is interesting.'

sen.j: 蹴鞠は貴族だけに止まらず、天皇、公家、将軍、武士、神官はては一般民衆に至るまで老若男女の差別無く親しまれた。
sen.e: Not only aristocrats, but also the emperors, Court nobles, shoguns, samurais, Shinto priests, and the general public, irrespective of age or gender, also liked kemari.
Not only aristocrats, but also the emperors, Court nobles, shogun, samurai, Shinto priests, and the general public, irrespective of age or gender, also liked kemari.
Not only aristocrats, but also the emperors, Court nobles, shogun, samurai, Shinto priests, and the general public, irrespective of age or gender, also liked kemari.

sen.j: 蹴鞠に関する種々の制度が完成したのは鎌倉時代で、以降近代に至るまでその流行は衰えることは無かった。
sen.e: Rules concerning kemari underwent various improvements and finally systematized in Kamakura Era. After then and until modern era, the popularity has never declined.
Rules concerning kemari underwent various refinements and were finally systematized in the Kamakura Era. Thereafter, the popularity had never declined.
Rules concerning kemari underwent various refinements and were finally systematized in the Kamakura period, thereafter, the popularity had never declined.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。Era→periodに変更しました。

sen.j: しかし室町時代の末期に織田信長が相撲を奨励したことで、蹴鞠の人気は次第に収束していったといわれる。
sen.e: However, in late Muromachi Era, because Nobunaga ODA encouraged sumo wrestling, it is said that the popularity of kemari was gradually brought to an end.
However, in late Muromachi Era, because Nobunaga ODA encouraged sumo wrestling, it is said that the popularity of kemari was gradually brought to an end.
However, in late Muromachi period, because Nobunaga ODA encouraged sumo wrestling, it is said that the popularity of kemari was gradually brought to an end.

sen.j: しかし蹴鞠の文化が消失した中国とは異なり、現代でも伝統行事として各地で蹴鞠が行われている。
sen.e: However, different from China, where the culture of kemari has disappeared, Japan still has kemari games held as traditional events in various places even at the present age.
However, different from China, where the culture of kemari has disappeared, Japan still has kemari games held as traditional events in various places even in the present day.
However, different from China, where the culture of kemari has disappeared, Japan still has kemari games held as traditional events in various places even in the present day.

sen.j: ルール
sen.e: Rules
Rules
Rules

sen.j: 蹴鞠は、懸（かかり）または鞠壺（まりつぼ）と呼ばれる、四隅を元木（鞠を蹴り上げる高さの基準となる木。
sen.e: Kemari was played inside a playground enclosed by motoki (elementary trees) at the four corners.
Kemari was played inside a playground enclosed by motoki (elementary trees) standing at the four corners.
Kemari was played inside a playground enclosed by motoki (elementary trees) standing at the four corners.

sen.j: ）で囲まれた三間程の広場の中で実施される。
sen.e: The playground was called kakari or maritubo of about 5.5 square meters.
The playground was called kakari or maritubo and was about 5.5 square meters.
The playground was called kakari or maritubo and was about 5.5 square meters.

sen.j: 1チーム4人、6人または8人で構成され、その中で径7～8寸の鞠をいくたび「くつ」をはいた足で蹴り続けられるかを競った団体戦と、鞠を落とした人が負けという個人戦があった。
sen.e: One team may be composed of four, people, six people or eight people. It might be a team competition in which a ball with diameter of about 21 cm to 24 cm was kept kicked by feet on "footwear", or it might be individual match in which the person who dropped the ball lost.

One team may be composed of four, people, six people or eight people. It might be a team competition in which a ball with diameter of about 21 cm to 24 cm was kept in the air by kicking using "footwear," or it might be an individual match in which the person who dropped the ball lost.

One team may be composed of four, people, six people or eight people, that might be a team competition in which a ball with diameter of about 21cm to 24cm was kept in the air by kicking using "footwear," or it might be an individual match in which the person who dropped the ball lost.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。スペース削除

sen.j: 懸 蹴鞠を行う競技場
sen.e: Kakari, a playground for kemari
Kakari, a playground for kemari
Kakari, a playground for kemari

sen.j: 元木 懸の四方に植えられたヤナギ（東南）、サクラ（東北）、マツ（西北）、カエデ（西南）などの植木。
sen.e: Motoki (Elementary trees): garden trees planted in the four directions of a Kakari: willow (southeast), cherry (northeast), pine (northwest), maple (southwest).
Motoki (Elementary trees): garden trees planted in the four directions of a Kakari: willow (southeast), cherry (northeast), pine (northwest), maple (southwest).
Motoki (Elementary trees): garden trees planted in the four directions of a Kakari: willow (southeast), cherry (northeast), pine (northwest), maple (southwest).

sen.j: 高さは一丈五尺以下で、鞠を蹴り上げる為の基準となった。
sen.e: A height of not exceeding 4.55 m became the standard for kicking the ball up.
A height not exceeding 4.55 m became the standard for kicking the ball up.
A height not exceeding 4.55m became the standard for kicking the ball up.

sen.j: 「きりたて」ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called "kiritate".
It is also called "kiritate".
It is also called 'kiritate.'

sen.j: 鞠足 蹴鞠を行うプレイヤー。
sen.e: Mariashi, player of kemari.
Mariashi, player of kemari.
Mariashi, player of kemari.

sen.j: 名プレイヤーを名足、下手な人を非足と呼んだ。
sen.e: A good player is called a "meisoku", while a bad player is called a "hisoku".
A good player is called a "meisoku," while a bad player is called a "hisoku".
A good player is called a "meisoku," while a bad player is called a "hisoku".

sen.j: 野伏 外に出た鞠を中へ蹴り返す補助役。
sen.e: Nobushi is an assistant who kicks a ball that goes outside back inside.
Nobushi is an assistant who kicks a ball that goes outside, back inside.
Nobushi is an assistant who kicks a ball that goes outside, back inside.

sen.j: 見証 審判。
sen.e: Witness, referee
Witness, referee
Witness, referee

sen.j: 上鞠 サッカーでいえばキックオフのこと。
sen.e: Agemari is an analog to the kickoff in a soccer game.
Agemari is an analog to the kickoff in a soccer game.
Agemari is an analog to the kickoff in a soccer game.

sen.j: 基本的に上鞠を行うことは非常に名誉なことであった。
sen.e: Basically, it was very honored to do the "kickoff".
Basically, it was a big honor to start the "kickoff".
Basically, it was a big honor to start the "kickoff."

sen.j: 請鞠 日暮や天候変化などにより、やむなく試合を中断すること。
sen.e: Ukemari is an unavoidable interruption of the game due to sunset, weather change, etc.
Ukemari is an unavoidable interruption of the game due to sunset, weather changes, etc.
Ukemari is an unavoidable interruption of the game due to sunset, weather changes, etc.

sen.j: 鞠
sen.e: ball
ball
Ball

sen.j: 蹴鞠の鞠は革製で、中空である。
sen.e: The ball of kemari is made of leather, and it is hollow inside.
The kemari ball is made of leather, and it is hollow inside.
The kemari ball is made of leather, and it is hollow inside.

sen.j: シカの滑革（ぬめかわ）2枚をつなぎあわせ、そのかさなる部分を、腰革、また「くくり」という。
sen.e: Two numekawa (leathers tanned with tannin) of deer are joined. The overlapped part is called, "koshikawa (waist leather)", or "kukuri (bundle)".
Two numekawa (leather tanned with tannin) of deer are joined together. The overlapped part is called, "koshikawa (waist leather)," or "kukuri (bundle),"
Two numekawa (leather tanned with tannin) of deer are joined together, and the overlapped part is called, koshikawa (waist leather), or 'kukuri (bundle).'
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。原文の「」に合わせ"を'に,→.

sen.j: また取革といって、べつに紫革の細いのをさしとおす。
sen.e: Also, they pierce through another thin murasaki-kawa (purple leather) called torikawa (attachment leather).
Also, another thin murasaki-kawa (purple leather) called torikawa (attachment leather) is attached.
Also, another thin murasaki-kawa (purple leather) called torikawa (attachment leather) is attached.

sen.j: 種類は、白鞠、生地鞠、燻鞠、唐鞠がある。
sen.e: The 4 types are shiromari (white ball), kijimari (material ball), kusubemari (smoked ball), and karamari (Chinese ball).
The 4 types are shiromari (white ball), kijimari (material ball), kusubemari (smoked ball), and karamari (Chinese ball).
The 4 types are shiromari (white ball), kijimari (material ball), kusubemari (smoked ball), and karamari (Chinese ball).

sen.j: 白鞠は鞠を白粉で塗ったもの。
sen.e: A white ball is painted with hakufun (white powder).
A white ball is painted with hakufun (white powder).
A white ball is painted with hakufun (white powder).

sen.j: 生地鞠は生地のままのもので、白鞠に対する。
sen.e: Contrary to the white ball, a material ball is without any paint.
Contrary to the white ball, a material ball is not painted.
Contrary to the white ball, a material ball is not painted.

sen.j: 燻鞠は燻革で製したもの。
sen.e: Kusubemari is made of kusube-gawa (smoked leather).
Kusubemari is made of kusube-gawa (smoked leather).
Kusubemari is made of kusube-gawa (smoked leather).

sen.j: 唐鞠は五色の革を縫いあわせて製し、中国から伝来したときの鞠のかたちであるという。
sen.e: The Chinese ball is sewed up of leathers five colors. It is said to be the original shape of the ball when it was introduced from China.
The Chinese ball is made of leather sewn up in five colors. It is said to be the original shape of the ball when it was introduced from China.
The Chinese ball is made of leather sewn up in five colors, and it is said to be the original shape of the ball when it was introduced from China.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: 「今川大草紙」によれば、「鞠皮は、春二毛の大女鹿の中にも、皮の色白で、爪にて押せば、しわのよる皮を上品とする也」という。
sen.e: It says in "Imagawa-ozoshi" that, "For marikawa (ball leather), the big doe with 2 colors in their fur during spring gives white and high-quality leather that pressing fingernails on the leather will cause wrinkles".

It says in "Imagawa-ozoshi" that, "For marikawa (ball leather), a big doe with 2 colors in their fur during spring gives a white and high-quality leather and that pressing fingernails on the leather will cause wrinkles..

It says in 'Imagawa-ozoshi' that, 'for marikawa (ball leather), a big doe with 2 colors in their fur during spring gives a white and high-quality leather and that pressing fingernails on the leather will cause wrinkles.'

sen.j: 革の縫いかた、取革については、「遊庭秘抄」に、「洛中に、河原院、又あまべとて、此の二ヶ条ならでは鞠くくりなし。
sen.e: About the sewing method of leathers and tokawa (attachment leather), in "Yuteihisho (Secret Book of Garden Games)", it says, "In Kyoto City, Kawara-no-in House and Amabe are the best. Except these two, no one can make balls.

sen.j: 河原院のまり、いかにもまさり、かた穴二つある鞠也。
sen.e: Balls of Kawara-no-in House are really superior balls with 2 leather holes.
Balls made by Kawara-no-in House are really superior with 2 leather holes.

sen.j: あまべの鞠は、かた穴二つある鞠也。
sen.e: Balls of amabe are balls with 2 leather holes..
Balls made by Amabe also have 2 leather holes..

sen.j: 縫ふ様は、針目も、又革も、五見え侍る様に、縫ふべし。
sen.e: The sewing is such that the stitch and also the leather in the way that five can be seen.
The ball is sewn in such a way that five sections can be easily seen.

sen.j: 或は七にも縫ふ也。
sen.e: Or in the way that seven can be seen.
Or in a way that seven sections can be seen.
Or in a way that seven sections can be seen.

sen.j: 韈の革の同色ならん革を、二分計に細く切つて、強くのして、かた穴の頭に穴をあけて、穴の中より革を引出して（革の先を結ぶべし）、かた穴の左の方に穴二つ、右の方に穴二をあけて、穴より入て小穴より出引て、はこの方を結で、かた穴の中（ままこひたひのそばなり）へさし入べし（両方如（レ）此）、取革といふ五分許の革を取、革の座敷に入とをして、両方の革のはたに穴をあけて、一方をさし入侍れば、革かいさまになるを、続飯にてつけて、さきをそとば頭に切也。
sen.e: A soft leather with the same color as shoe is cut exactly into two thin parts. It is stretchy extended. In the part of the leather for a hemisphere, a hole is made. From that hole, a leather is pull out and tied up at this side. In the left of the leather hole, make 2 holes. In the right of the leather hole, make 2 holes. The attachment leather goes in the big hole and comes out from the small holes and ties up at this side. Then, it should be inserted into the leather hole to the forehead of a stepchild. Both leather holes are done like this with about 1.5 cm of the attachment leather put into the place for this leather. To the ends of both leathers, a hole is made. From each end, leather is inserted and crossed the other. They are stuck by sokui (paste made of glutinous rice) and the ends are cut by the head part of a sotoba.

A soft leather with the same color as shoe leather, is cut exactly into two thin parts. It is stretched and extended. In the part of the leather used for a global shape, a hole is made. From that hole, a piece of leather is pull out and tied at the side. Left of the leather hole, make 2 holes. In the right hole, make 2 holes. The leather attachment goes into the big hole and comes out the small holes and is tied. Then, it should be inserted into the leather hole to the forehead of a stepchild. Both leather holes are done like this with about 1.5 cm of the attached leather put into the place for this leather. To the ends of both leathers, a hole is made. From each end, leather is inserted and crossed the other. They are stuck by sokui (paste made of glutinous rice) and the ends are cut by the head part of a sotoba.
sen.cmt: Sorry, but this description is incomprehensible. A picture of the ball would help in correcting this description.
sen.e: A soft leather with the same color as shoe leather, is cut exactly into two thin parts. It is stretched and extended. In the part of the leather used for a global shape, a hole is made. From that hole, a piece of leather is pull out and tied at the side. Left of the leather hole, make 2 holes. In the right hole, make 2 holes. The leather attachment goes into the big hole and comes out the small holes and is tied. Then, it should be inserted into the leather hole to the forehead of a stepchild. Both leather holes are done like this with about 1.5cm of the attached leather put into the place for this leather. To the ends of both leathers, a hole is made. From each end, leather is inserted and crossed the other. They are stuck by sokui (paste made of glutinous rice) and the ends are cut by the head part of a sotoba.

sen.j: 取革付けぬ鞠は、今に忌中の鞠に取革付侍ぬ也。
sen.e: A ball without the attachment leather is a ball in mourning at present.
A ball without the attachment leather is a ball in mourning at present.
A ball without the attachment leather is a ball in mourning at present.

sen.j: 可（レ）得（二）其意（一）」（（一）、（二）、（レ）は、返り点。）という。
sen.e: Thus, one can know the meaning."
Thus, one can know the meaning."
Thus, one can know the meaning.'

sen.j: 各時代において多数の名足を生み出したが、平安後期の藤原成通は特に希代の名人と言われ、後世の蹴鞠書でも「蹴聖」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: There were a lot of great Kemari players throughout in each era. However, FUJIWARA-no-Narimichi of the late Heian Era was said to be an especially unprecedented expert. Even in the Kemari literature thereafter, he was called the "saintly kicker".

There were a lot of great Kemari players throughout each era. However, FUJIWARA-no-Narimichi of the latter Heian period was said to be an especially unprecedented expert. Even in later Kemari literature, he was called the "saintly kicker."

There were a lot of great Kemari players throughout each era, however, FUJIWARA no Narimichi of the latter Heian period was said to be an especially unprecedented expert, who, in later Kemari literature, was called the 'saintly kicker.'
sen.cmt: スペース削除一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。名前の-削除原文の「」に合わせ"を'に

sen.j: 成通が蹴鞠の上達のために千日にわたって毎日蹴鞠の練習を行うという誓いを立てた。
sen.e: In order to excel in kemari, Narimichi made an oath of practicing kemari every day for 1000 days.
In order to excel in kemari, Narimichi made an oath to practice kemari every day for 1000 days.
In order to excel in kemari, Narimichi made an oath to practice kemari every day for 1000 days.

sen.j: その誓いを成就した日の夜のこと、彼の夢に3匹の猿の姿をした鞠の精霊が現れ、その名前（夏安林（アリ）、春陽花（ヤウ）、桃園（オウ））が鞠を蹴る際の掛声になったと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that at the night of the day when the oath was accomplished, three spirits of kemari appeared as three monkeys playing kemari in his dream. Their names Geanrin (ari), Shunyoka (yau), and Toen (ou) became the shouts when kicking a kemari.

It is said that at the night of the day when the oath was taken, three kemari spirits appeared as three monkeys playing kemari in his dream. Their names Geanrin (ari), Shunyoka (yau), and Toen (ou) became the shouts when kicking a kemari.

It is said that at the night of the day when the oath was taken, three kemari spirits appeared as three monkeys playing kemari in his dream, that were called as Geanrin (ari), Shunyoka (yau), and Toen (ou) became the shouts when kicking a kemari.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。

sen.j: この3匹の猿は蹴鞠の守護神として現在、大津の平野神社と京都の白峯神宮内に祭られている。
sen.e: As the guardian gods for kemari, these three monkeys are at present enshrined in Hirano-jinja Shrine of of Otsu and Shiramine-jingu Shrine of Kyoto.
As the guardian gods for kemari, these three monkeys are at present enshrined in Hirano-jinja Shrine of Otsu and Shiramine-jingu Shrines of Kyoto.
As the guardian gods for kemari, these three monkeys are at present enshrined in Hirano-jinja Shrine of Otsu and Shiramine-jingu Shrines of Kyoto.

sen.j: また、その名前から猿田彦を守護神とする伝承もあった事が『節用集』に書かれている。
sen.e: Moreover, from the names, there was also a legend that made Sarutahiko the guardian god, as written in the book "Setuyoshu".
From the names, there was also a legend that made Sarutahiko the guardian god, as was written in the book "Setuyoshu".
From the names, there was also a legend that made Sarutahiko the guardian god, as was written in the book "Setuyoshu."

tit.e: A family with kemari as the family business
A family with kemari as the family business
A family with kemari as the family business

sen.j: 難波家（難波流）
sen.e: The Namba family (the Namba school)
The Namba family (the Namba school)
The Nanba family (the Nanba school)

sen.j: 藤原頼輔 - 難波宗長と飛鳥井雅経の祖父
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Yorisuke - Grandfather of Munenaga NAMBA and Masatsune ASUKAI
FUJIWARA no Yorisuke - Grandfather of Munenaga NAMBA and Masatsune ASUKAI
FUJIWARA no Yorisuke - Grandfather of Munenaga NANBA and Masatsune ASUKAI

sen.j: 難波宗長 - 難波流祖
sen.e: Munenaga NAMBA - the founder of the Namba school
Munenaga NAMBA - the founder of the Namba school
Munenaga NANBA - the founder of the Nanba school

sen.j: 飛鳥井家（飛鳥井流）
sen.e: The Asukai family (the Asukai school)
The Asukai family (the Asukai school)
The Asukai family (the Asukai school)

sen.j: 飛鳥井雅経 - 飛鳥井流祖
sen.e: Masatsune ASUKAI - the founder of the Asukai school
Masatsune ASUKAI - the founder of the Asukai school
Masatsune ASUKAI - the founder of the Asukai school

sen.j: 飛鳥井雅庸
sen.e: Masatsune ASUKAI
Masatsune ASUKAI
Masatsune ASUKAI

sen.j: 御子左家・冷泉家（御子左流）
sen.e: The Mikohidari family, the Reizei family (the Mikohidari school)
The Mikohidari family, the Reizei family (the Mikohidari school)
The Mikohidari family, the Reizei family (the Mikohidari school)

sen.j: 藤原為家 - 御子左流祖
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Tameie - the founder of the Mikohidari school
FUJIWARA no Tameie - the founder of the Mikohidari school
FUJIWARA no Tameie - the founder of the Mikohidari school

sen.j: 公家の流派のうち難波流・御子左流は近世までに衰退したが、飛鳥井流だけはその後まで受け継がれていった。
sen.e: Among the schools of the nobility, the Namba school and the Mikohidari school had declined by the early modern age. Afterwards, only the Asukai school continued to succeeded.
Among the schools of the nobility, the Namba and the Mikohidari schools had declined by the early modern age. Afterwards, only the Asukai school continued.
Among the schools of the nobility, the Nanba and the Mikohidari schools had declined by the early modern age, afterwards, only the Asukai school continued.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。Namba →Nanbaに変更しました。

sen.j: 飛鳥井家屋敷の跡にあたる白峯神宮の精大明神は蹴鞠の守護神であり、現在ではサッカーを中心としたスポーツ・芸能の神とされている。
sen.e: The Sei-daimyojin (Energetic Great Gracious Deity) in Shiramine Jingu Shrine in the residential site remain of the Asukai family, was a patron saint of kemari. Now, it is regarded as the god of sports and public entertainments centered on soccer.

The Sei-daimyojin (Energetic Great Gracious Deity) in Shiramine Jingu Shrine in the remains of the residential site of the Asukai family, was a patron saint of kemari. Now, it is regarded as the god of sports and public entertainment centered on soccer.

The Sei-daimyojin (Energetic Great Gracious Deity) in Shiramine-jingu Shrine in the remains of the residential site of the Asukai family, was a patron saint of kemari, therefore now it is regarded as the god of sports and public entertainment centered on soccer.
sen.cmt: 一文一訳文にするため訂正しました。-jingu修正

sen.j: 毎年4月14日と7月7日には蹴鞠奉納が行われる。
sen.e: On April 14 and July 7 every year, kemari is held as a dedication offering.
On April 14 and July 7 every year, kemari is held as a dedication offering.
On April 14 and July 7 every year, kemari is held as a dedication offering.

sen.j: 賀茂氏・賀茂神社（社家流）
sen.e: The Kamo clan, Kamo-jinja Shrine (the Shake school)
The Kamo clan, Kamo-jinja Shrine (the Shake school)
The Kamo clan, Kamo-jinja Shrine (the Shake school)

sen.j: 賀茂成平 - 社家流祖
sen.e: KAMO no Narihira - the founder of the Shake school
KAMO no Narihira - the founder of the Shake school
KAMO no Narihira - the founder of the Shake school

sen.j: 賀茂御祖神社では現在でも毎年1月4日に「蹴鞠はじめ」が行われている。
sen.e: On January 4 every year, "first kemari for the New Year" is still held in Kamomioya-jinja Shrine.
On January 4 every year, "first kemari for the New Year" is still held in Kamomioya-jinja Shrine.
On January 4 every year, 'first kemari for the New Year' is still held in Kamomioya-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: なお下鴨神社は日本サッカー協会のシンボルマークのモチーフでもある「八咫烏」を祭っている。
sen.e: Shimogamo-jinja Shrine also enshrines "Yatagarasu (a holy crow leading Emperor Jinmu)", which is also the motif of the emblem of Japan Football Association.
Shimogamo-jinja Shrine also enshrines "Yatagarasu (a holy crow leading Emperor Jinmu)," which is also the motif of the emblem of The Japan Football Association.
Shimogamo-jinja Shrine also enshrines 'Yatagarasu' (a holy crow leading Emperor Jinmu), which is also the motif of the emblem of The Japan Football Association.
